DOC.brief_title: Intermittent Hypoxia Elicits Prolonged Restoration Motor Function Human SCI
DOC.detailed_description: : The goal study determine whether repeatedly breathe low oxygen level brief period ( termed intermittent hypoxia ) improve limb function spinal cord injury . This idea stem animal study respiration , investigator show mild intermittent hypoxia improve breathe spinally injure rat . These study show intermittent hypoxia induces spinal plasticity , strengthen neural connection motor neuron function within spinal cord . Exposure mild intermittent hypoxia trigger cascade event , include increase production key protein increase sensitivity spinal cord circuitry necessary improve breathing . The investigator initially hypothesize daily exposure intermittent hypoxia 7 consecutive day improve limb function rat humans chronic spinal injury . First , investigator compare limb function spinally-injured rat receive mild intermittent hypoxia treatment rat . The investigator measure grip strength locomotor abilities group treatment several month treatment . The investigator also examine spinal cord rat look key protein , indicator spinal plasticity . The investigator use information guide treatment protocols investigator compare limb function spinal-injured person without intermittent hypoxia treatment . The second hypothesis combine intermittent hypoxia locomotor train improve limb function spinal injury . To test idea , investigator compare limb function spinally-injured rat receive combined intermittent hypoxia treadmill train rat receive intermittent hypoxia locomotor train alone . The investigator examine key protein spinal cord rat determine whether combination hypoxia training alters indicator plasticity . The investigator also compare limb function spinally-injured human receive intermittent hypoxia locomotor treadmill train receive either treatment alone . The ultimate goal research assess potential mild intermittent hypoxia therapeutic approach stimulate recovery limb function human patient .
DOC.criteria: medical clearance participate lesion C5 T12 nonprogressive etiology classify motorincomplete injury great 12 month ambulatory minimal assistance Concurrent severe medical illness ( i.e. , infection , cardiovascular disease , ossification , recurrent autonomic dysreflexia , unhealed decubiti , history cardiac pulmonary complication ) Pregnant woman unknown affect AIH pregnant woman fetus History seizure , brain injury , and/or epilepsy Diagnosed obstructive sleep apnea Undergoing concurrent physical therapy Any contraindication EMG test procedure ( skin sensitivity ) Any contraindication passive movement limb ( e.g. , joint immobility , hemodynamic instability ) Score < 24 MiniMental Exam
